title: Finding Nemo 3D
critics_consensus: Breathtaking animation, talented vocal work, and a well-written screenplay add up to another Pixar success.

title: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey
critics_consensus: Peter Jackson's return to Middle-earth is an earnest, visually resplendent trip, but the film's deliberate pace robs the material of some of its majesty.

title: Les Miserables
critics_consensus: Impeccably mounted but occasionally bombastic, Les Miserables largely succeeds thanks to bravura performances from its distinguished cast.

title: Django Unchained
critics_consensus: Bold, bloody, and stylistically daring, Django Unchained is another incendiary masterpiece from Quentin Tarantino.

title: Cloud Atlas
critics_consensus: Its sprawling, ambitious blend of thought-provoking narrative and eye-catching visuals will prove too unwieldy for some, but the sheer size and scope of Cloud Atlas are all but impossible to ignore.

title: Silver Linings Playbook
critics_consensus: Silver Linings Playbook walks a tricky thematic tightrope, but David O. Russell's sensitive direction and some sharp work from a talented cast gives it true balance.

title: Lincoln
critics_consensus: Daniel Day-Lewis characteristically delivers in this witty, dignified portrait that immerses the audience in its world and entertains even as it informs.

title: Killing Them Softly
critics_consensus: Killing Them Softly is a darkly comic, visceral thriller that doubles as a cautionary tale on capitalism, whose message is delivered with sledgehammer force.

title: Texas Chainsaw
critics_consensus: As an ugly and cynical attempt to rebrand Leatherface as horror anti-hero, Texas Chainsaw 3D is a bold move for the franchise.

title: Gangster Squad
critics_consensus: Though it's stylish and features a talented cast, Gangster Squad suffers from lackluster writing, underdeveloped characters, and an excessive amount of violence.

title: Zero Dark Thirty
critics_consensus: Gripping, suspenseful, and brilliantly crafted, Zero Dark Thirty dramatizes the hunt for Osama bin Laden with intelligence and an eye for detail.

title: Mama
critics_consensus: If you're into old-school scares over cheap gore, you'll be able to get over Mama's confusing script and contrived plot devices.

title: A Haunted House
critics_consensus: undefined

title: This is 40
critics_consensus: Judd Apatow definitely delivers funny and perceptive scenes in This is 40, even if they are buried in aimless self-indulgence.

title: Jack Reacher
critics_consensus: Jack Reacher is an above-average crime thriller with a smoothly charismatic performance from Tom Cruise.

title: Safe Haven
critics_consensus: Schmaltzy, predictable, and melodramatic, Safe Haven also suffers from a ludicrous plot twist, making for a particularly ignominious Nicholas Sparks adaptation.

title: Parental Guidance
critics_consensus: Parental Guidance is sweet but milquetoast, an inoffensive trifle that's blandly predictable.

title: Side Effects
critics_consensus: A smart, clever thriller with plenty of disquieting twists, Side Effects is yet another assured effort from director Steven Soderbergh.

title: The Guilt Trip
critics_consensus: Seth Rogen and Barbra Streisand have enough chemistry to drive a solidly assembled comedy; unfortunately, The Guilt Trip has a lemon of a script and is perilously low on comedic fuel.

title: The Impossible
critics_consensus: The screenplay isn't quite as powerful as the direction or the acting, but with such an astonishing real-life story at its center, The Impossible is never less than compelling.

title: Beautiful Creatures
critics_consensus: Charming romantic leads and esteemed supporting cast aside, Beautiful Creatures is a plodding YA novel adaptation that feels watered down for the Twilight set.

title: Broken City
critics_consensus: Broken City's thinly sketched, formulaic script offers meager rewards for all but the least demanding noir aficionados.

title: Parker
critics_consensus: Jason Statham is game as usual, but Parker is a thoroughly generic and convoluted heist movie.

title: The Last Stand
critics_consensus: There's nothing particularly distinguished about it, but for Schwarzenegger fans The Last Stand provides perfectly undemanding entertainment.

title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone)
critics_consensus: undefined

title: The Collection
critics_consensus: The Collection offers more grisly thrills and twisted humor than its predecessor; in other words, fun for genre fans, but unpleasant for anyone else.

title: Promised Land
critics_consensus: The earnest and well-intentioned Promised Land sports a likable cast, but it also suffers from oversimplified characterizations and a frustrating final act.

title: A Royal Affair
critics_consensus: A Royal Affair is a lavish and sumptuous costume drama with a juicy story to back it up.

title: Stand Up Guys
critics_consensus: Stand Up Guys largely wastes its talented cast in a resolutely mediocre comedy hampered by messy direction and a perfunctory script.

title: To the Arctic
critics_consensus: undefined

title: Hyde Park on Hudson
critics_consensus: Though bolstered by a thoroughly charming performance by Bill Murray in the central role, Hyde Park on Hudson is an FDR biopic that lets down both its audience and its subject.

title: Bachelorette
critics_consensus: It has its moments, but Bachelorette ultimately plays it too safe with its trio of unlikable leads, betraying them with a predictably sentimental final act that undermines the bracingly honest humor preceding it.

title: The Haunting in Connecticut 2: Ghosts of Georgia
critics_consensus: undefined

title: The Sorcerer and the White Snake
critics_consensus: undefined

title: Wuthering Heights
critics_consensus: Director Andrea Arnold's gritty, naturalistic re-imagining of the Emily Bronte classic stays true to the book's spirit while utilizing an unconventional approach to explore the romantic yearning at the heart of the story.

title: The ABCs of Death
critics_consensus: As is often the case with anthology films, The ABCs of Death is wildly uneven, with several legitimately scary entries and a bunch more that miss the mark.

title: Hitler's Children
critics_consensus: undefined

title: John Dies at the End
critics_consensus: Some will find the darkly funny, genre-bending incoherence of John Dies at the End charming; some will feel its zany antics and gore lead to an unsatisfying payoff.

title: The Central Park Five
critics_consensus: undefined

title: Dragon
critics_consensus: undefined

title: Struck by Lightning
critics_consensus: undefined

title: Bad Kids Go to Hell
critics_consensus: undefined

title: Upstream Color
critics_consensus: As technically brilliant as it is narratively abstract, Upstream Color represents experimental American cinema at its finest -- and reaffirms Shane Carruth as a talent to watch.

title: The Other Son
critics_consensus: undefined

title: The Sweeney
critics_consensus: Ray Winstone exudes tough-guy bravado, but this cop thriller otherwise feels thoroughly generic.

title: The Oranges
critics_consensus: Despite the efforts of its accomplished cast, The Oranges suffers from a mediocre script that fails to deliver well-rounded characters, dramatic tension, or sufficient laughs.

title: Any Day Now
critics_consensus: undefined

title: A Monster in Paris
critics_consensus: undefined

title: The Details
critics_consensus: undefined

title: A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III
